_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Anhydrous ammonia tank exterior, PSV's, pump and valve inspection.
Denaturant tank high level alarm and exterior tank inspection.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Bridgeport Ethanol, LLC

Bridgeport Ethanol, LLC (Bridgeport) owns and operates a nameplate 60,000,000 gallon per year (60 MMgal/yr) denatured fuel-grade ethanol and industrial grade undenatured ethanol plant. Plant construction began in September 2007 and operations began in November 2008. At that time, BRIDGEPORT submitted an RMP for the facility in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68.  Over the years, improvements have been made and production has increased by nearly 20,000,000 MMgal/yr.  

The Bridgeport ethanol plant utilizes corn (grain) to produce ethanol via natural fermentation. These activities fall under Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) 2869, Industrial Organic Chemicals, Not Elsewhere Classified. The plant generates fuel-grade ethanol, primarily for blending with motor fuels. The ethanol may be blended with approximately 2.5% gasoline in the final denaturing stages of the process, or it may be left undenatured. The plant also generates carbon dioxide, corn oil, and wet distiller's grain and solubles (WDGS), which are sold as animal feed.

Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

Bridgeport is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Bridgeport's investment in accident prevention, through the establishment of a facility that is well designed, installed, operated, and maintained. In addition, training is considered a crucial part of safe operation and accident prevention. Staff are trained about spill prevention and control methods as well as emergency response plans that are in place at the facility.

It is Bridgeport policy to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances and if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary. Bridgeport management is dedicated to safety, spill prevention and proper emergency response.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Bridgepo

rt is located approximately one mile southeast of Bridgeport, Morrill County, Nebraska on a 43 acre parcel of land that is bounded by Country Roads 90 and 92 and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad.

The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from corn. The substances which Bridgeport has onsite that are regulated by the RMP program are Anhydrous Ammonia and Denaturant (natural gasoline) which is considered a flammable mixture.  The anhydrous ammonia is used as a chemical processing aid and is consumed in the manufacturing process. It is stored in a single anhydrous ammonia tank. The denaturant (natural gasoline) is used to denature the ethanol so that it is unfit for human consumption before being shipped offsite. Denaturant is stored onsite in the denaturant and final product storage tanks. 

Five Year Accident History

Bridgeport has been subject to RMP criteria since it began storing anhydrous ammonia and denaturant (natural gasoline) onsite.
In the past five years, Bridgeport has had no reportable accidents.

Emergency Response Program Information

Bridgeport is registered with the Morrill County, NE LEPC and does have its own Emergency Response Plan for emergencies requiring a low or medium amount of emergency support. In the case that an incident occurred which required high level emergency response, Bridgeport would call 911 for the necessary fire, medical or other emergency support.  Bridgeport Ethanol has its own Hazwoper team and contracts with outside contractors to provide timely spill cleanup and disposal.  

As explained above, Bridgeport is committed to worker and public safety and has invested in training and equipment to prevent chemical spills and other emergency situations. In the event of a chemical spill, plant personnel would respond to contain the release, as necessary. Some physical aspects of the plant would also help the personnel contain a potential spill. For example,

all tanks that contain denaturant are located in a large, bermed containment area that is separated from the plant.  A release from one of these tanks would be prevented from migrating off-site, and a fire could be extinguished before it spreads to other units at the facility.  In addition, a manual shut off valve near the ammonia tank and an emergency stop would help limit the volume of an ammonia spill.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Bridgeport is subject to RMP Prevention Program Level 3.  Bridgeport is fulfilling its duties to comply with the EPA requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.115(d) through the completion of this RMP and similar efforts regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  Bridgeport has complied with Process safety information, safe work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and maintenance procedures are documented on-site. Periodic functions such as process hazard analyses (PHA), training, management of change, compliance audits, pre-startup safety reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis.
  
The denaturant tank is equipped with tank level sensors and alarms as well as a bermed containment structure that surrounds the entire tank farm.  The anhydrous ammonia tank is equipped with a manual shut off valve and emergency stops.  Both the denaturant tanks and anhydrous ammonia tank receive five year and ten year internal and external inspections as required by OSHA PSM.  These chemical specific prevention measures minimize the risk for an RMP reportable incident.  Compliance audits of the RMP Prevention Program will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA and OSHA regulations. 

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As previously mentioned, Bridgeport is committed to protecting its employees, the greater community, and the environment from the release of hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production proces

s. Bridgeport management is committed to promoting a safe work environment and will continue to provide its employees with the necessary training, tools, and ongoing support to operate the ethanol production facility in a safe and efficient manner. Periodic audits will help us assure that we are doing everything reasonable to minimize the risk of and mitigate the effects of an accidental release.

Selection of Worst Case and Alternative Release scenarios

The facility has selected the included worst case and alternative release scenarios based on a prior recommendation from a third-party environmental contractor with 35 years experience in the ethanol production and chemical manufacturing fields.  The scenarios used for the RMP products are releases that did or could reasonably happen at an ethanol production facility of Bridgeport Ethanols size.
